awd_titl_txt: Manipulating Supramolecular Assembly in Water and Aqueous Mixtures
awd_abstract_narration:
Deep cavity cavitands are container-shaped supramolecular complexes that contain a one-nanometer, rigid, non-polar binding pocket and a hydrophilic exterior coating that bestows good water solubility. Cavitands have proven useful "hosts" because of their ability to bind other molecules, or "guests", within their pockets and assemble in well-defined stoichiometries. They have applications in studies of protein solubility, in controlled release of pharmaceuticals, in separations, in the precise control of photochemical reactions, and as gelling agents.  The fundamental understanding of these supramolecular complexes requires a molecular-level understanding of the interactions between hosts and guests in solution. A collaborative research project is proposed that combines molecular simulation and experimental studies aimed at investigating the impact of aqueous mixtures with co-solvent and polymeric additives on the forces driving cavitand assembly.

The overarching goal of the proposed research is to develop molecular tools for controlling supramolecular cavitand assembly by manipulating the solvent properties that mediate host/guest interactions. The following topics will be studied: 1) How do alcoholic co-solvents moderate cavitand binding and assembly thermodynamics for a series of amphiphilic and non-polar guests? 2) How do changes in the hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity of the functional groups ringing the cavitand host pocket portals impact pocket hydration thermodynamics, drying/filling kinetics, and guest binding affinities?  3) What is the impact of water-soluble polymer crowding agents on the stability of moderately stable dimeric cavitand complexes?  Molecular dynamics simulations of guest binding and cavitand complex formation will be performed over a range of solvent conditions and cavitand functions to examine water and alcohol structural correlations with host/guest complexes, complexation thermodynamics, wetting of host binding pockets, and osmotic stresses to gain molecular-scale insights into the forces stabilizing these assemblies. Complementary experiments will be performed to examine the effects of host functions and aqueous mixture compositions on the resulting cavitand complexes, using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance and light scattering, and the underlying assembly thermodynamics, using calorimetry.  In addition to graduate and undergraduate student training, the proposed project will include an outreach program to the New Orleans Charter Science and Mathematics High School that serves a predominantly underrepresented minority student base.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Initial work under this grant examined the impact of potential cononsolvency driven effects on cavitand host binding with guests and the impact of macromolecular crowding on cavitand capsular assembly. Cononsolvency is the effect that a mixture of two different solvents, like water and ethanol, is a worse solvent for a solute than either solvent alone. As such, this could lead to more favorable assembly in mixed solvents. While our molecular simulations predicted much strong binding of hydrophobic guests to cavitands in 10 mol% ethanol solutions in water, our experiments did not find this effect. Moreover, solubility limitations limited our ability to screen a wider range  solution conditions.

 

Macromolecular crowding is the effect that the addition of soluble macromolecular species to solution can lead to effective depletion interactions that can strengthen self-assembled structures. This effect is widely recognized in the protein folding literature. Using molecular simulations we have demonstrated that adding poly(ethylene oxide) to water leads to much stronger assembly of cavitand hosts into dimeric capsules, in agreement with the expectations of molecular crowding theories. Experimental verification of this effect, however, has been more daunting as a result of the complexity of the solutions.

 

A new avenue of investigation that opened up over the course of this grant was the experimental observation that the interactions between charged cavitand hosts and charged guests do not follow the expectations based on their charges. Specifically we expect that oppositely charge species will interaction more strongly that similarly charged species. Our experiments found, however, that negatively charged hosts and guests interact with similar strength to oppositely charged hosts and guests, while positively charged hosts and guests interact significantly more weakly. Our molecular simulations have reproduced this experimental finding, indicating that the molecular foundations for this phenomena are captured by our simulation models. By the process of elimination, we have shown that this must arise from a water specific effect, but the non-trivial surface topography makes identification of the specific water structural differences harder. Nevertheless, clues are being found. For instance we have found that cationic cavitands are more strongly wetted than their anionic counterparts as illuminated by measurements of the free energy to dehydrate the hydrophobic pockets of the cation hosts.

 

Our insights into dewetting contributions to the interactions between cavitands and non-polar guests led us to revisit the theoretical underpinnings of hydrophobic hydration. Specifically, we found that the Gaussian fluctuations of water density within an observation volume that are normally thought to arise from the structure of water actually obey a relatively simple functional form over all length-scales that could be well described using an analytical form. This theory was shown to seamlessly mesh with a surface tension based description of the formation of air bubbles in solution. The resulting analytical theory describes hydrophobic hydration from molecular to macroscopic length scales. While not perfect, it represents a significant advance building on the previous information theory description put forward in the 1990s. Moreover, the simplicity of the theory enables rapid predictions using only a spreadsheet. The inputs into the theory are such that it can potentially discriminate between many simulation description of water and =provide new insights into why water is such a unique solvent. Indeed, most non-aqueous solvents do not obey Gaussian statistics at the molecular scale, raising new questions.


Last Modified: 04/11/2023
Modified by: Henry S Ashbaugh
